title: ddbar lemma
summary: In complex geometry, the ∂ ∂ ¯ {\displaystyle \partial {\bar {\partial }}} lemma (pronounced ddbar lemma) is a mathematical lemma about the de Rham cohomology class of a complex differential form. The ∂ ∂ ¯ {\displaystyle \partial {\bar {\partial }}} -lemma is a result of Hodge theory and the Kähler identities on a compact Kähler manifold. Sometimes it is also known as the d d c {\displaystyle dd^{c}} -lemma, due to the use of a related operator d c = − i 2 ( ∂ − ∂ ¯ ) {\textstyle d^{c}=-{\frac {i}{2}}(\partial -{\bar {\partial }})} , with the relation between the two operators being i ∂ ∂ ¯ = d d c {\displaystyle i\partial {\bar {\partial }}=dd^{c}} and so α = d d c β {\displaystyle \alpha =dd^{c}\beta } .[1]: 1.17 [2]: Lem 5.50
